Name: Contract Tailor Processor (ContractManager **)

Documentation.Description:
Basic Concepts

ContractManager is a REST based client that exposes two @POST methods:
  • @sendContract which translates an IncentivePlan (marked as "Compliant" by the market regulator) into a Contract proposal Orion entity,
  • @updateContract which allows the e-marketplace customer user interface to accept or reject the contract proposal by updating the Orion entity status.

Basic Design Principles

The following picture gives a snapshot of the java classes that have been developed for ContractManager:


Figure 1: ContractManager domain model
Documentation.Details:
IMPORTANT: we kindly remind you that this software module is strictly tight to the use of ORION Context Broker GE thus meaning that you should have previously set up an ORION instance of yours. Please have a look at ORION GE documentation at the following link http://catalogue.fi-ware.org/enablers/publishsubscribe-context-broker-orion-context-broker

Download the artefact (in the form a .war file) from the bottom of the page.
Open the .war file (you can use an appropriate software like “winRar”), open the “contractManager.properties” file located in the following directory: WEB-INF/classes/ and then amend the following configuration properties: 

contractManager.orionServerUrl = http://(your ORION instance URL):1026
contractManager.registerContexPath = NGSI10/updateContext

Save the changes to the .properties file and deploy the .war file on a Tomcat application server using the “Tomcat Web Application Manager” (see attached screenshot). We recommend you to use an updated version of Tomcat; we have used Apache Tomcat 7.xx.


Figure 2: How to the deploy the contractManager.war file

In order to verify that the deploy of the contractManager application has been done successfully and that it consequently runs, you have to type the following URL in a common browser like Google Chrome or Microsoft Internet Explorer: 

http://(your tomcat ip)/contractManager/rest/sendContractData

and you should get a page like the following (see attached screenshot).


Figure 3: Test "sendContract" GET method in a browser

If the previous page appears, the ContractManager application is correctly deployed.

SEND CONTRACT
Now, in order to send a “Contract” to ORION, use a REST client such as DHC - REST/HTTP API Client chrome extension (see attached screenshot):


Figure 4: Send a "Contract data" to ORION

Please fill in with the following parametres:
SERVICE (POST) 

http://(your tomcat ip)/contractManager/rest/sendContractData/byIncentivePlan

HEADERS 

Content-Type: application/xml

BODY 

<notifyContextRequest>
  <subscriptionId>51c04a21d714fb3b37d7d5a7</subscriptionId>
  <originator>(your tomcat host)</originator>
  <contextResponseList>
    <contextElementResponse>
      <contextElement>
        <entityId type="IncentivePlan" isPattern="false">
          <id>Incentive1</id>
        </entityId>
        <contextAttributeList>
          <contextAttribute>
            <name>IPId</name>
            <type>string</type>
            <contextValue>incentive_1</contextValue>
          </contextAttribute>
          ..................
          ..................
          <contextAttribute>
            <name>Incentive1Offer</name>
            <type>string</type>
            <contextValue>your offer</contextValue>
          </contextAttribute>
          ..................
          ..................
          <contextAttribute>
            <name>State</name>
            <type>string</type>
            <contextValue>Compliant</contextValue>
          </contextAttribute>
        </contextAttributeList>
      </contextElement>
      <statusCode>
        200
        <reasonPhrase>OK</reasonPhrase>
      </statusCode>
    </contextElementResponse>
  </contextResponseList>
</notifyContextRequest>
EOF

and finally click the SEND button.

If you get 200 OK in the HTTP Response, you should have submitted a “contract” to ORION (what we have previously defined as a new "Contract proposal" for the final customer).

In order to verify that a new “Contract” has been saved into ORION, an entity of the following type should be created (or updated in case it already exists) in the NoSQL DB underlying ORION (i.e. MongoDB):

UPDATE CONTRACT
Now, in order to update a “Contract” to ORION (due to the fact that a final customer has approved a "Contract proposal"), use a REST client such as DHC - REST/HTTP API Client chrome extension (see attached screenshot):


Figure 4: Update "Contract data" in ORION

Please fill in with the following parametres:
SERVICE (POST) 

http://(your tomcat ip)/contractManager/rest/sendContractData/byCustomer

HEADERS 

Content-Type: application/xml

BODY 

<updateContextRequest>
  <contextElementList>
    <contextElement>
      <entityId type="Contract">
        <id>contract2orion</id>
      </entityId>
      <contextAttributeList>
        <contextAttribute>
          <name>currentTime</name>
          <type>sec</type>
          <contextValue>1423154331</contextValue>
        </contextAttribute>
        <contextAttribute>
          <name>contractId</name>
          <type>int</type>
          <contextValue>IncentivePlan_energy-retailer_1423578590_0512690040069_1423578805</contextValue>
        </contextAttribute>
        <contextAttribute>
          <name>i1CustomerApproval</name>
          <type>int</type>
          <contextValue>yes</contextValue>
        </contextAttribute>
        <contextAttribute>
          <name>DateOfApproval</name>
          <type>sec</type>
          <contextValue>1423154331</contextValue>
        </contextAttribute>
        <contextAttribute>
          <name>State</name>
          <type>string</type>
          <contextValue>Approved</contextValue>
        </contextAttribute>
      </contextAttributeList>
    </contextElement>
  </contextElementList>
  <updateAction>APPEND</updateAction>
</updateContextRequest>
EOF

and finally click the SEND button.

If you get 200 OK in the HTTP Response, you should have updated a “contract” into ORION (the incentive n.1 has been accepted by the customer and its state has turned to "yes"; the "State" attribute of the "Contract" entity has turned to "Approved" thus meaning that the final customer has approved a "Contract proposal" which a Retailer had submitted to him/her).

In order to verify that a “Contract” has been updated into ORION, an entity of the following type should be updated in the NoSQL DB underlying ORION (i.e. MongoDB). In the entity below, only the "updated" atrributes are shown: 

{
  "_id" : {
    "id" : "contract2orion",
    "type" : "Contract" 
  },
  "attrs" : [{
      "name" : "currentTime",
      "type" : "sec",
      "creDate" : 1423578592,
      "modDate" : 1423578592,
      "value" : "1423578805" 
    }, {
      "name" : "contractId",
      "type" : "string",
      "creDate" : 1423578592,
      "modDate" : 1423578592,
      "value" : "IncentivePlan_energy-retailer_1423578590_0512690040069_1423578805" 
    }, .......
................
..............
....... {
      "name" : "i1CustomerApproval",
      "type" : "int",
      "creDate" : 1423578592,
      "modDate" : 1423578592,
      "value" : *1*
    }, .............
...............
................
... {
      "name" : "dateOfApproval",
      "type" : "string",
      "creDate" : 1423578592,
      "modDate" : 1423578592,
      "value" : "1423154331" 
    }, {
      "name" : "State",
      "type" : "string",
      "creDate" : 1423578592,
      "modDate" : 1423578592,
      "value" : *Approved*
    }],
  "creDate" : 1423578592,
  "modDate" : 1423578592
}

Address/Protocol

The address of the REST calls invoking the ContractManager service depends on the IP address/port of the application server where the module is going to be deployed. 

EXAMPLE: http://(your tomcat ip)/contractManager/rest/sendContractData/byIncentivePlan
EXAMPLE: http://(your tomcat ip)/contractManager/rest/sendContractData/byCustomer

Protocol: HTTP

Commands

The following HTTP commands can be used to manipulate the data controlled by the DSE:
  • HTTP GET command used to test if the module has been properly installed; a simple XML, such the one shown below, is expected as output:

<contract>
<currentTime>1435053274078</currentTime>
<dateOfCreation>0</dateOfCreation>
<dateOfApproval>0</dateOfApproval>
<contractID>Contract1</contractID>
<incentivePlanID>incentive_1</incentivePlanID>
<customerID>customer1</customerID>
<ip1_value>0.0</ip1_value>
<ip1_start>0</ip1_start>
<ip1_end>0</ip1_end>
<ip1_customerApproval>0</ip1_customerApproval>
<ip2_value>0.0</ip2_value>
<ip2_start>0</ip2_start>
<ip2_end>0</ip2_end>
<ip2_customerApproval>0</ip2_customerApproval>
<ip3_value>0.0</ip3_value>
<ip3_start>0</ip3_start>
<ip3_end>0</ip3_end>
<ip3_customerApproval>0</ip3_customerApproval>
<ip4_value>0.0</ip4_value>
<ip4_start>0</ip4_start>
<ip4_end>0</ip4_end>
<ip4_customerApproval>0</ip4_customerApproval>
<ip5_value>0.0</ip5_value>
<ip5_start>0</ip5_start>
<ip5_end>0</ip5_end>
<ip5_customerApproval>0</ip5_customerApproval>
</contract>

  • HTTP POST to send new information to the module.

Endpoints

1) The base URI to invoke the rest method exposed by ContractManager which allow a contract proposal to be submitted is: 

http://(your tomcat ip)/contractManager/rest/sendContractData/byIncentivePlan

The is a POST method which needs the following parameters to be submitted: 

currentTime
IPId
customerId
meterId
Incentive1PlanTarget
Incentive1Type
Incentive1Value
Incentive1StartDateTime
Incentive1EndDateTime
Incentive1Offer
..............
..............
..............
..............
Incentive5PlanTarget
Incentive5Type
Incentive5Value
Incentive5StartDateTime
Incentive5EndDateTime
State

2) The base URI to invoke the rest method exposed by ContractManager which allow a contract proposal to be approved is: 

http://(your tomcat ip)/contractManager/rest/sendContractData/byCustomer

The is a POST method which needs the following parameters to be submitted: 

currentTime
contractId
i1CustomerApproval
i2CustomerApproval
i3CustomerApproval
i4CustomerApproval
i5CustomerApproval
dateOfApproval
State
Documentation.Preface:
Within this document you find a self-contained open specification of the aforementioned Domain Specific Enabler (DSE).

Please consult the appropriate pages on the FINESCE website in order to understand the complete context of the related FINESCE trials and this DSE.

Dario Pellegrino (Engineering Ingegneria Informatica S.p.A.) - dario.pellegrinoREMOVE-NO-SPAM@eng.it
Overview:
What you get

ContractManger is a REST service (developed in Java) which
  • translates the incentives included in an IncentivePlan (issued by a Retailer) into a new Contract proposal that will be saved into an ORION Context Broker GE instance,
  • updates an existing contract with content coming from a contract proposal "approved" by the final customer.

This component can be eventually re-used and customized to fulfill the general need of having a REST service which is connected to the ORION GE.

Why to get it

A reference implementation of a REST service which is connected to the ORION GE.

Target Usage

  • Within an Energy Marcketplace, it can represent a tool to automatically translate IncentivePlans into Contract proposals for final customers.
  • Third-party applications (such as those developed by SMEs involved in Phase3)
